Best cycling mitts 2023: Buyer’s guide to fingerless cycling gloves

Cycling mitts are a great option for keeping your hands protected in the warmer months, when long finger gloves don’t quite fit the bill. While they serve a similar function, short-finger mitts are designed with better airflow and lighter fabrics in mind to help keep your hands cool during hotter temperatures.

As with winter gloves, technical details will vary from mitt to mitt, with different types of material, padding, fit and closure mechanisms. We’ve tested mitts from some of the most popular brands to give you a full rundown of the best options. Keep reading for our breakdown and to find the best cycling mitts for you this summer, starting with our favourites and working our way down.

Dhb Aeron short finger gloves 2.0

RRP: £25

Sizes available: XS-XXL Colours available: Black, blue, red, white

The Dhb Aeron Short Finger 2.0s are a set of great value all-rounder cycling mitts that cover all the bases. They have an adjustable cuff, with 4mm gel/foam padding which is used in three locations across the palm and has silicone detailing for grip.

The upper is highly stretchy and breathable and the fit allows good hand movement without being loose. The padding is minimal but effective and damps road vibrations without feeling overly bulky.

Cycling mitt buying advice: everything you need to know

Do I need to wear cycling mitts?

While wearing gloves, like many things in cycling, is a matter of personal preference, there are some key safety and comfort benefits to wearing cycling mitts. They include:

  • Crash protection: should you get in an accident, mitts provide a crucial barrier to protect your skin against the ground and can prevent or reduce the risk of substantial grazing/injury
  • Day-to-day protection: mitts act as a barrier between you and your handlebars and, much as socks prevent blisters, can help reduce chafing and irritation when riding for long periods of time by reducing the direct friction to the skin
  • Reduced rumble: the padding in mitts helps damp the vibrations transmitted to us from the road through our bike and handlebars. Over long periods of time, this can help fatigue levels as your body isn’t having to absorb as much movement and can help with overall comfort
  • Sweat wipe: fingerless mitts are aimed at warmer weather riding and most will have some sort of towelling panel to use to wipe sweat from your face to keep it out of your eyes

How do I choose the right cycling mitts for me?

There are four main elements to consider when picking cycling mitts: padding, breathability, fit and price. Most gloves will do one or two of these pretty well but ideally aim for mitts that cover all the bases at a reasonable price. Just because a set of mitts is more expensive doesn’t mean they’re automatically better quality or better suited to your needs.

Why are mitts fingerless?

Cycling mitts are designed for use in warmer weather, when traditional winter gloves would be too hot. The cut-off shape allows for air to flow up through the finger holes and helps with overall breathability and comfort levels. If the shape isn’t for you, another option is lightweight XC-style full-finger gloves which balance breathability and protection.

Which is better for cycling mitts, Velcro fastening or pull-on?

Both closure mechanism come with advantages and disadvantages. Velcro fastenings allow for more precision and let you tailor the wrist size to how you like it, however some can find the added seams and stitching irritating or uncomfortable. Pull-on mitts generally have fewer seams and are more minimal, though the fit can’t be adjusted and the fabric can sometimes become loose over time.
